The argument that God cannot exist due to the amount and degree of evil present in the world is often proposed by atheists and agnostics. There is an acknowledgement in that statement that evil does, in fact, exist. 
 
 But can evil exist in the context of a purely materialistic atheism/agnosticism?
 
 Does the statement above refute theism or atheism?
 
 This article, The Problem of Evil by Benjamin D. Wiker explores that idea:
 
 http://www.crisismagazine.com/december2003/feature1.htm 
 
 Please read the article if you are so inclined and comment.

post_info.post_title: Can evil exist without God? With atheism?

The argument that God cannot exist due to the amount and degree of evil present in the world is often proposed by atheists and agnostics. There is an acknowledgement in that statement that evil does, in fact, exist. 
 
 But can evil exist in the context of a purely materialistic atheism/agnosticism?
 
 Does the statement above refute theism or atheism?
 
 This article, The Problem of Evil by Benjamin D. Wiker explores that idea:
 
 http://www.crisismagazine.com/feature1.htm 
 
 Please read the article if you are so inclined and comment.

 
 Perhaps they might have to admit that evil is relative.

But can evil exist in the context of a purely materialistic atheism/agnosticism?

I think it is only logical as an atheist to say that evil is a relative term and thus does not truly exist.

 Do you think it's wrong, or 'evil' (see below)
 
 
 
 
 e·vil **(vl)
 adj. e·vil·er, e·vil·est Morally bad or wrong; wicked: an evil tyrant. 
 Causing ruin, injury, or pain; harmful: the evil effects of a poor diet. 
 Characterized by or indicating future misfortune; ominous: evil omens. 
 Bad or blameworthy by report; infamous: an evil reputation. 
 Characterized by anger or spite; malicious: an evil temper. 
 
 n. The quality of being morally bad or wrong; wickedness.
 That which causes harm, misfortune, or destruction: a leader's power to do both good and evil. 
 An evil force, power, or personification.
 Something that is a cause or source of suffering, injury, or destruction: the social evils of poverty and injustice. 
 
 adv. Archaic In an evil manner.
 http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=evil

 Poet,
 I think that is a tap dance. You don't approve of murder in any way but why not? "Just an action" does not elicit a judgment on whether that action is something to be approved or not. Breathing may be just an action, walking may be just an action but there are no judgments of approval needed for things that are "just actions." Why can't someone murder another and say "no big deal, evil is relative?" There may be some gradations and shades of good and evil, but these gradations are rooted in an objective good and evil.
 
 Have you seen the stories on TV about the kids going around and videotaping themselves walking up to someone randomly on the street and punching his lights out? Do you think there is evil in that random act of maliciousness that has no motive but to inflict pain and to revel in that infliction of pain?

I think that is a tap dance. You don't approve of murder in any way but why not? "Just an action" does not elicit a judgment on whether that action is something to be approved or not. Because you cause negative impulses or energy thus creating a worse short life span for myself as well as others to live with. I do not want killers to affect my short time here in existance. Nor does anyone else.

Define 'negative' then! You don't believe in 'right' or 'wrong' but 'negative' and 'positive' that is one interesting tap dance

 
 By human standards it is wrong to murder. But I don't beleive in universal right and wrong.
 
 A negative impulse would be demonstrated in the feeling of pain or sadness.
 For instance my friend stabs my hand with a pen. While I don't beleive this is universally wrong it is wrong by law and by societial standards. The negative impulse is the pain I feel from that stab.

By human standards it is wrong to murder. But I don't beleive in universal right and wrong.

 
 Yes, you do. You just said that 'human standards' murder is wrong. That would make it universal, at least amongst humans!
 
 
 
A negative impulse would be demonstrated in the feeling of pain or sadness.

 
 By that rationale, any murder which you don't feel something about, such as an emotional response, is okay.
 
 
 For instance my friend stabs my hand with a pen. While I don't beleive this is universally wrong it is wrong by law and by societial standards. The negative impulse is the pain I feel from that stab.

 
 Therefore it is wrong, only for you, becuase only you are feeling the pain. It is right for the person stabbing you.
 
 However, even you now appeal to something higher than yourself; law and society.
 
 If you just believe that things are wrong by law or societal standards, I assume you mean by the laws of the US or whatever nation you're from... because laws and societies vary, thus you'd have to be arguing that what is right or wrong varies.
 
 Therefore, when someone molests a child - it should be looked in cultural context and is not absolutely wrong.
 
 How do you go about changing a law? You must be against it; almost any political action, because you won't be able to decide what's right or wrong - unless you personally feel something like an emotion or physical pain.
 
 Further, you must be in a dilemma. Your nation acts on the world stage, suggesting accordances with other nations. You must agree with them all - because it is lawful for your nation to act in such a manner, and it is in agreement with the society test - unless you don't live in a democracy.
 So, when your nation acts for you, regardless of what it does - such as invade a nation (for self-defence), you have to agree with it... until such time that it becomes unpopular - and therefore society is against it. Thence the dilemma, which force do you back, society or law? I guess you wait to see which one causes you emotional pain, and judge by that.
 
 You can't rely on emotions all the time. Who is to say that your emotional response is correct. You must be very violent - if someone causes you pain, it is wrong, therefore you must act to prevent that wrong - so much for turning the other cheek.
 
 
 I hope I've not put too many words in your mouth :) I am only trying to extrapolate from the ideas you've presented.

Montalban,
 
 
Yes, you do. You just said that 'human standards' murder is wrong. That would make it universal, at least amongst humans!

 This is not all that difficult but I'm going to try to explain it one more time.
 
 I have my own opinions on what people should and should not do. They are formed various ways. 
 Everyone has their own opinions on what people should and should not do. On some of these issues, the majority of people and myself agree and on some they do not.
 Why?
 Because good and evil are relative terms to describe actions, or thoughts.
 They are relative to every person, society, culture, government, law system, etc...
 
 The above is my view point as an atheist.
 If I were to be a theist then I would not see good or evil as relative terms. Rather I would seem them as "universal" because they would be predetermined and defined by God.
 
 Thus from my atheist view, "universal" good and evil do not truly exist. But despite this I do often refer to things good and evil as based on a general human scale.

I'm not sure.

 But keep this in mind...if you believe there is no God then you should not believe in inalienable rights. For, if inalienable rights are granted by man, then man can at any time decide to take those rights away. Therefore, they are not truly inalienable, and no truly inalienable right can exist...no life, no liberty, no pursuit of happiness. Crim,

Maximus,
 
 I haven't been following this thread and on first glance, that article is pretty long. Gimme a day or so and I'll look it over.

Poet:
 
 I have been reading through some of this thread. I am curious about your statments and how you fit them together with your claim that Arafat should be removed. You can answer in this thread or that. I am just interested in how you get your reasoning. I really won't argue with you.

SilentPoet's reasoning is interesting. I think we agree that he doesnt approve of actions that harm himself or others. that would be his definition of "wrong". However, "harm" in itself is a relative word, since some people enjoy being spanked, just as some people are terrified of rollercoaster rides
 
 what I'm really interested in hearing more about from SilentPoet about his concept of "negative and positive energy". Could you discuss more on that?

The argument that God cannot exist due to the amount and degree of evil present in the world is often proposed by atheists and agnostics. There is an acknowledgement in that statement that evil does, in fact, exist. 
 
 But can evil exist in the context of a purely materialistic atheism/agnosticism?
 
 Does the statement above refute theism or atheism?

 First of all, whether exists "evil" is merely a matter of the definition of the word
 
 1. Morally bad or wrong; wicked
 2. Causing ruin, injury, or pain; harmful
 
 the first definition only applies if you believe in some set of absolute principles. the second definition is easier for atheists to relate to.
 
 I think that in either case, we all agree that evil does currently exist
 
 would it exist without the existence of God? OK, first there are lots of people that believe God does not exist, yet they agree that evil exists
 
 I personally think that evil would exist simply based on the existence of free will. if man has an imagination that can invent options, and a free will that can allow him to choose those options and act on those options, then the choice to harm another will alway exist, and therefore the action of harming others will alway exist.
 
 finally, its very interesting that the argument "there is evil, therefore God doesnt exist" comes head to head with the subject of this thread
 
 God is benevolent and loving
 but evil exists
 therefore God doesnt exist
 therefore absolute morals dont exist
 therefore "right" or "wrong" doesnt exist
 therefore evil doesnt exist
 
 the presence of evil in the world seems to substantiate the existence of God rather that disprove it. Because if it is somehow found that God truly doesnt exist, then who will we hold accountable for all the evil in the world? would it be then apparent that evil is nothing but the consequences of man's choices? would this congizance cause people to be more conscious of the impact of their actions and repent of their wrong?

Mr. Jack,
 You may be interested in this thread as it addresses the post you made on your new thread, "The Problem of Evil."
 
 Read all of the posts if you're interested or simply click on this link and read the article:
 
 http://www.crisismagazine.com/december2003/feature1.htm 
 
 See what you think.

I'll give you my answer:
 
 I'm an atheist. I don't believe in objective evil. However this does not let the theist's off the hook with the problem of evil. The Problem of Evil is an exercise in looking from the point of view of the Theist and seeing what happens, and under the Theistic worldview there is objective evil.
 
 I found the article to be another exercise in 'god moves in mysterious ways' question dodging. I am uninpressed by any argument that is based on anything along the lines of 'god is so much bigger and smarter than us, we can't possible understand'. Not because it is necessarily untrue, but because it completely avoid any possibility of rational discussion. It can be an answer to anything, and so is an answer to nothing.
 
 I found as well its insistence on equating evolution and atheism tiring.

I'll give you my answer:
 
 I'm an atheist. I don't believe in objective evil. However this does not let the theist's off the hook with the problem of evil. The Problem of Evil is an exercise in looking from the point of view of the Theist and seeing what happens, and under the Theistic worldview there is objective evil.
 
 I found the article to be another exercise in 'god moves in mysterious ways' question dodging. I am uninpressed by any argument that is based on anything along the lines of 'god is so much bigger and smarter than us, we can't possible understand'. Not because it is necessarily untrue, but because it completely avoid any possibility of rational discussion. It can be an answer to anything, and so is an answer to nothing.
 
 I found as well its insistence on equating evolution and atheism tiring.

 The point that the article asserts is that evil is just as much a problem for the atheistic view as for the theistic one. In a pure material atheism there can be no evil. There is only generic action...fate...chance...randomness. However, one can see the reality of evil in this world (more aptly one can feel evil when he has been wronged himself)--malice, calculated violence, verbal abuse, domestic abuse, rape, greed, etc.
 
 If there is no objective evil (as you contend) then there is no problem for theists or atheists. If there is evil, neither side can fully explain it but it makes more sense in the theistic view than the atheistic one. Evil may be a "problem" but it is not a problem that disproves God.

Even in theology there is no "good" or "evil". It is a political term. Good means you are aligned with God and Evil of the Devil. Hence God=G(o)od Devil= D(e) evil (of evil). So there is no absolute.
 
 Take murder. Murdering a adulterer was Good because God told the israelites to do it. People that didn't were evil. Now God decides to changed the rules now murdering an adulterer is evil.
 
 The same goes for society. All nations give the government the right as a sorverign state to murder who it chooses. There are generally laws that make it politically unfriendly in conservative nations but it is still murder.
 
 In theism God defines good and evil. In atheism self defines good and evil. No big deal since God is an Atheist it makess sense.

It might seem at this point that the problem of evil has been solved and that, as it turns out, evil is not really a problem after all. Once we realize that there is so little agreement on what is evil or what to do about it, and that our merely human judgment is either stunted or partial, then we must confess that our complaints are without merit. Only God could know the big picture, and into that picture backaches and headaches, cancer, cats playing with mice, parasites, floods, Nazis, slavery, and starving children all somehow fit..
 

 The article you cite, maximus, although interesting, does a fantastic job of skirting the issue. The author concludes again that evil is in human choices, which is where we begin in the catch-22 of the God-created-evil question.
 
 Many people do not believe in a supernatural or religious origin of evil, but that "evil" is indeed in our options and choices. Believing in evolution and a lack of morality in nature is not at all incongruous with believing in human morality, despite the author's claims about evolution and moral lassitude. 
 
 It is the theist who creates the conundrum when they say that God created everything, and that there is a force of evil in the world (the devil). If you are an atheist who believes in a force of evil, indeed then you have to come up with an origin, but you are still not faced with the contradiction of saying that a God who is love created evil.

If there is no objective evil (as you contend) then there is no problem for theists or atheists. If there is evil, neither side can fully explain it but it makes more sense in the theistic view than the atheistic one.

 
 I disagree. Whether there is objective evil or not is dependent on whether the theist or the atheist is right. If there is a god (actually, if there are certain kinds of god) then there is objective evil. If there is no god there is not.

I don't understand the objective evil concept. There is no "good" or "evil". In the gardern of eden evil was eating from the wrong tree. Billions of people are killed and tortured for it. Eating from the tree did not hurt anyone nor did it cause any physical pain. The objective evil concept doesn't make any sense. Evil is subjective. The only difference is Theist use Gods definition of evil vs mans.

It is the theist who creates the conundrum when they say that God created everything, and that there is a force of evil in the world (the devil). If you are an atheist who believes in a force of evil, indeed then you have to come up with an origin, but you are still not faced with the contradiction of saying that a God who is love created evil.

 
 We do not believe that God created evil. We believe that he allowed the possiblity of it via free will. But I guess that is what is being discussed on the "Problem of Evil" thread. I will check it out.

But can evil exist in the context of a purely materialistic atheism/agnosticism?

 
 Yes. But if you rephrased the question as "Does evil exist independent of an observer with a cohesive values system?", I'd say "no". That an event is regarded as evil requires a values system, but not necessarily theism.
 
 
 
Does the statement above refute theism or atheism?

 
 IMHO, no.
 
 
 Regards,
 mrmufin

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Can evil exist without God? With atheism?
